body: Yup, that's a bug, thank you! Not sure if there's a _good_ solution, but the least we could do is pick a more suitable color.
Would 0xFF00FF be appropriate? I typically use that as a to-become-transparent colour.

I cannot reproduce the trailing issue that the color key code is supposed to work around on either Windows 7 (Intel and Nvidia) or Windows 10 (Intel and Nvidia). I'm inclined to say it was a bug in earlier versions of Windows 10 and remove the workaround altogether.

Is this workaround still needed ? I had a hole in my window because i was rendering a pink image (testing some opengl shader), I thought it was a bug in my shader.
Maybe this should be mentioned in the GLFW window guide.
@BFavier Good point. It really needs to be.

So, after coming to GLFW after using Direct2D, I feel obligated to point out that WS_EX_LAYERED hasn't been required for transparency for a while. If you simply don't set WS_EX_LAYERED (or remove it after creating the window), everything works fine, because now windows ignores the color key and correctly composites. I'm pretty sure whatever bug this was working around only applied before Windows 7.
@ErikMcClure Ooh, I will look into this. Thank you! We do still support Windows XP but hopefully not for much longer.

Even if you are supporting XP, surely you could at least put in a compile switch to disable this behavior? Or even [dynamically detect whether or not the system is XP](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/sysinfoapi/nf-sysinfoapi-getversion) and only enable the flag if it is XP.
@ErikMcClure I cannot reproduce the issue that led to the color key hack on either Windows 7 or 10 on any GPU, so I'd be fine with removing it and seeing if any issues pop up.

No, never mind, the bug is still there.

I tried to figure out why this bug happens but failed.  I did however figure out more about when it happens, which is on Windows 7 when DWM is enabled but transparency effects are disabled. The `win32-colorization-opacity` branch is the result and my proposal for resolving this issue.
That fix seems reasonable and should keep weird behavior from happening in windows 10
